content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Supine position, lower limb in slight external rotation, with the knee maintained at approximately 20-30° of flexion[3]

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the medial tibiofemoral joint line, medial tibial plateau, and tibial tuberosity

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Examination of the tendons constituting the pes anserinus complex
positionnement: In longitudinal view (parallel to the long axis of the tibia), place the probe at the level of the anteromedial aspect of the medial tibial plateau

To guide the necessary rotation angle, you can start with an axis almost parallel to that formed by the femoral shaft (see adjacent image), and then adjust the rotation angle until an adequate image is obtained

texte: The tibia appears in the lower half of the image, and its cortical bone appears as a thick horizontal hyperechoic line.

The tendons of the pes anserinus complex, which cannot be differentiated from each other, are partially visible just superficial to the tibia. Even though the tendon margins are not clearly defined, it is possible to follow the course of the tendons by recognizing their fibrillar echotexture typical of tendon tissue.

text: The term 'pes anserinus complex' refers to the anatomical site where a group of three muscles located on the medial aspect of the thigh insert. In order from anterior to posterior, these are: the sartorius (formerly called the tailor's muscle); the gracilis; and the semitendinosus. These three muscles originate at the pelvic girdle, their muscle bellies traverse the medial aspect of the femur, and they finally insert on the anteromedial aspect of the proximal tibia. The choice of the term is explained by the overall appearance of the three flattened tendons at their insertion, which vaguely resembles the appearance of a goose's foot[3].

The pes anserinus complex is located approximately 5-6 cm distal (caudal) to the medial tibiofemoral joint line. When these tendons are observed distally (close to their insertion), it should be noted that they are very closely superimposed on each other, and evaluation using ultrasound imaging does not allow them to be differentiated. In contrast, if observation is performed at a more proximal site (e.g., opposite the cranial portion of the popliteal fossa), it is generally easy to differentiate the tendons of these three muscles, which may (or may not) contain muscular tissue, as the location of the musculotendinous junctions is subject to some variability[3].

Under the pes anserinus complex lies the distal attachment of the medial collateral ligament, which has been the subject of a protocol on Physiographie. Additionally, it is common to find a bursa positioned between the bone surface and the tendons of the pes anserinus complex, although this is quite inconsistent[3].

content.subtitle: Pes Anserinus Tendinopathy/Bursopathy
text: The term 'pes anserinus tendino-bursitis syndrome' is frequently used in scientific literature, as well as the terms 'pes anserinus syndrome' or 'pes anserinus tendinitis/bursitis'. It is common for the clinical diagnosis of this condition to be based solely on signs and symptoms which, unfortunately, lead to divergent interpretations and nomenclature[4]. Some authors even report that the anatomical structure causing the symptoms is not identified, hence the lack of consensus in the literature[2].

Pes anserinus tendino-bursitis is a frequent cause of medial knee pain, especially in people who are obese, have type II diabetes, knee osteoarthritis, or valgus knee deformity[2]. Classically, the clinical presentation includes pain in the medial aspect of the knee, accompanied by tenderness on palpation of the inferomedial region of the knee[1].

In the presence of a subject where pes anserinus tendino-bursitis is suspected, ultrasound imaging is recognized as a reliable technique, capable of highlighting pes anserinus tendino-bursitis. According to a consensus established by the European Society of Musculoskeletal Radiology, this imaging technique is strongly recommended, due to a level '3' evidence (according to the Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine scale), which means that ultrasound is a first-choice technique, and other techniques rarely provide additional significant information. However, it should be noted that the majority of the literature is based on case studies or extrapolations from retrospective studies (grade 'C' for methodology)[7].
